articles.headline: A Catch-22 in Kenya: Western Terrorism Alerts May Fuel Terrorism
articles.snippet: Local officials see Western travel warnings as a reason for the collapse of tourism and hope that they will not become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
articles.abstract: Local officials see Western travel warnings as a reason for the collapse of tourism and hope that they will not become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOMBASA, Kenya — Every morning at the Tides Inn, a waiter trudges down from the restaurant to the beach with a huge blackboard advertising the daily specials — deep-fried fish and masala prawns, pepper steak and pizza, all listed in chalk and illustrated with cute drawings.

articles.headline: States Are Blocking Local Regulations, Often at Industry’s Behest
articles.snippet: So-called pre-emption laws, passed in states across the country, have stopped cities from regulating landlords, building municipal broadband systems and raising the minimum wage.
articles.abstract: So-called pre-emption laws, passed in states across the country, have stopped cities from regulating landlords, building municipal broadband systems and raising the minimum wage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Darren Hodges, a Tea Party Republican and councilman in the windy West Texas city of Fort Stockton, is a fierce defender of his town’s decision to ban plastic bags. It was a local solution to a local problem and one, he says, city officials had a “God-given right” to make.

articles.headline: Funding Fight Over Homeland Security Poses Dangers for the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: A partisan impasse over immigration could cause funding for the agency to run out Friday and damage the Republican brand, and the impact could carry over into the next election cycle.
articles.abstract: A partisan impasse over immigration could cause funding for the agency to run out Friday and damage the Republican brand, and the impact could carry over into the next election cycle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After promising an era of responsible governing and an end to federal shutdowns, congressional Republicans find themselves mired in an immigration fight that could cause funding for the Department of Homeland Security to run out on Friday.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: She Runs S.E.C. He’s a Lawyer. Recusals and Headaches Ensue.
articles.snippet: The agency’s director, Mary Jo White, must recuse herself from cases handled by her former law firm as well as her husband’s firm, sometimes leaving a party-line stalemate.
articles.abstract: The agency’s director, Mary Jo White, must recuse herself from cases handled by her former law firm as well as her husband’s firm, sometimes leaving a party-line stalemate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Their legal careers, and by extension their marriage, are the stuff of lore. Mary Jo White leads the Securities and Exchange Commission; her husband, John, practices law at an old-guard firm as elite as the corporations it represents. Together, they are a legal power couple that straddles Wall Street and Washington like few others.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

articles.headline: A Pesticide Banned, or Not, Underscores Trans-Atlantic Trade Sensitivities
articles.snippet: Diverging regulatory approaches to atrazine, a herbicide made by a Swiss company but not used in Europe, shows the hurdles in trade negotiations.
articles.abstract: Diverging regulatory approaches to atrazine, a herbicide made by a Swiss company but not used in Europe, shows the hurdles in trade negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Syngenta, a Swiss chemicals company, produces one of America’s most popular herbicides. It is called atrazine, and 73.7 million pounds of the chemical compound were applied in the United States in 2013. It was used on more than half of all corn crops, two-thirds of sorghum and up to 90 percent of sugar cane.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Issues Stiffer Rules on Vehicle Fuel Ratings
articles.snippet: Starting next year, automakers will face tougher guidelines around how they conduct a test used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.
articles.abstract: Starting next year, automakers will face tougher guidelines around how they conduct a test used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After two years of imposing increasingly stiff penalties on automakers that overstate their fuel economy ratings, federal regulators on Monday said they would tighten guidelines used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.

articles.headline: Amex’s Loss in Court May Not Help Consumers
articles.snippet: If history is any guide, the ruling against American Express will not lead to the desired outcome of increased competition and lower prices.
articles.abstract: If history is any guide, the ruling against American Express will not lead to the desired outcome of increased competition and lower prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, a federal judge handed down a major ruling against American Express, deciding that the brand-name card issuer had engaged in anticompetitive practices for more than a decade.

articles.headline: Bill O’Reilly and Fox News Redouble Defense of His Falklands Reporting
articles.snippet: On Monday’s show, Mr. O’Reilly played CBS News footage from 1982 that showed violent protests and quoted correspondents describing the scene, but former colleagues said his account was still flawed. (With video.)
articles.abstract: On Monday’s show, Mr. O’Reilly played CBS News footage from 1982 that showed violent protests and quoted correspondents describing the scene, but former colleagues said his account was still flawed. (With video.)
articles.lead_paragraph: The Fox News host Bill O’Reilly on Monday stepped up his defense against reports that he embellished stories about his war reporting earlier in his career, while some former colleagues continued to say he had exaggerated his experiences.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Cause Célèbre, Scorned by Troops
articles.snippet: Thousands have signed a petition on behalf of First Lt. Clint Lorance, who was convicted of murder in the killing of two Afghan civilians. His platoon is not backing the effort.
articles.abstract: Thousands have signed a petition on behalf of First Lt. Clint Lorance, who was convicted of murder in the killing of two Afghan civilians. His platoon is not backing the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen soldiers from an Army platoon were on patrol in a dangerous valley in southern Afghanistan when a motorcycle sped toward them, ignoring commands to stop.

articles.headline: Fed’s Janet Yellen, in Testimony, Counsels Patience on Interest Rate Increase
articles.snippet: Ms. Yellen said the next step would be an announcement that the Federal Reserve would begin to consider raising its benchmark rate at each policy-making meeting.
articles.abstract: Ms. Yellen said the next step would be an announcement that the Federal Reserve would begin to consider raising its benchmark rate at each policy-making meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Tuesday that the central bank is pleased with recent economic growth but convinced there is room for improvement and still pondering when to start raising interest rates.
